In case the two (2) arbitrators appointed by the Parties do not agree on this choice with [*****] from the date the last arbitrator is appointed, the third arbitrator will be appointed by the ICC Court.
perturbation.changed_text: 5.2.1 Subject to sub-Clause 5.2.5 below and in the event the Representatives (i) fail to create such committee or (ii) do not agree on an amicable settlement within [*****] from the date the committee referred to in this sub-Clause 5.2 has been created or such longer period as may be agreed upon in writing by the Representatives (the "Amicable Settlement Period"), the Dispute shall be exclusively and finally settled under the Rules and Conciliation of Arbitration of the International Chamber of Commerce (the "ICC") by an arbitral tribunal composed of three (3) arbitrators; each Party shall then appoint one (1) arbitrator within *one (1) day* from the last day of the Amicable Settlement Period and the third arbitrator, who will act as President, will be appointed by the other two (2) arbitrators. In case the two (2) arbitrators appointed by the Parties do not agree on this choice with *one (1) day* from the date the last arbitrator is appointed, the third arbitrator will be appointed by the ICC Court.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the time frame to appoint the arbitrator to one day is extremely unreasonable, this timeframe is insufficient to allow a party reasonable time to select a qualified arbitrator, thus undermining the fairness and enforceability of the arbitration clause. This contradicts the principle of fairness and due process inherent in arbitration law.

perturbation.original_text: 5.2.3 The arbitration shall be kept confidential and the existence of the proceeding and any element of it shall not be disclosed to any third party. Any information relating to and/or documents generated for the purpose of or produced in the arbitration, including any awards, shall remain confidential between the Parties, the arbitrators and any other Person involved in the arbitration proceedings, except to the extent that disclosure may be required pursuant to any order of court or other competent authority or tribunal, or to protect or pursue a legal rights or to enforce or challenge an award in bona fide legal proceedings before a state court or other judicial authority.
perturbation.changed_text: 5.2.3 The arbitration shall be kept confidential and the existence of the proceeding and any element of it shall not be disclosed to any third party. Any information relating to and/or documents generated for the purpose of or produced in the arbitration, including any awards, shall remain confidential between the Parties, the arbitrators and any other Person involved in the arbitration proceedings, *with no exceptions*.
perturbation.explanation: Removing the exception for disclosures required by court order or to enforce legal rights creates an illegal confidentiality provision. Courts generally require transparency in legal proceedings and preventing a party from disclosing information necessary to enforce an arbitration award is against public policy and potentially violates legal and ethical obligations. Arbitral proceedings must comply with fundamental tenets of due process and transparency, including the ability to disclose information when compelled by law or necessary for enforcement.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Federal Arbitration Act, court rulings related to transparency in legal proceedings
